Introduction

The pulmonary circulation refers to blood flow from the right side of the heart, through the lungs, and to the left side of the heart.  Normal pulmonary circulation is a low-resistance, low-pressure system.  This article discusses the factors that influence pulmonary vascular resistance and the ways that the right ventricle (RV) responds to changes in its afterload.

Properties



In anatomic order, the pulmonary circulation includes the RV, RV outflow tract, main pulmonary artery (PA), pulmonary arterial branches, pulmonary arterioles, pulmonary capillaries, pulmonary venules, pulmonary veins, and left atrium (LA).



The pulmonary circulation handles the same cardiac output (CO) as the systemic circulation, in keeping with the continuity of flow principle (Qpulmonary = Qsystemic).  To accommodate this same flow within the lungs' smaller volume, the pulmonary circulation has high compliance.  Pulmonary arteries have thinner walls with less elastin and smooth muscle, allowing greater distensibility compared to systemic arteries.  Along with its high compliance, the pulmonary circulation is a low-resistance, low-pressure system:



  • Low resistance:  Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is approximately one-sixth of systemic vascular resistance (SVR):  PVR = 30-200 dynes·s/cm5, whereas SVR = 800-1200 dynes·s/cm5.
  • Low pressure:  Mean PA pressure (mPAP) is approximately one-sixth of mean arterial pressure (MAP):  mPAP = 15 mm Hg, whereas MAP = 90 mm Hg.

Right heart catheterization

Procedure



Right heart catheterization (ie, Swan-Ganz) records pressures at key points in the pulmonary circulation (

figure 1
).  A catheter is introduced via the internal jugular or femoral veins and advanced into the superior vena cava.  Waveform and pressure readings are captured at the following:



  • Right atrium:  The classic central venous waveform (a, c, v, x, y) is seen (
    figure 2
    ).  The average value of all wave heights is the mean right atrial pressure.
  • RV:  When the catheter enters the RV, a sine waveform appears, ranging from 0-5 mm Hg at the end of diastole to approximately 25 mm Hg during peak systole.
  • PA:  As the catheter advances from the RV into the main PA, a pressure step-up occurs immediately after the catheter crosses the pulmonic valve.  Unlike the RV, the PA retains pressure during diastole due to vascular resistance and pulmonic valve closure.  This establishes a PA diastolic pressure (dPAP), which is approximately 10 mm Hg.  The PA systolic pressure (sPAP) closely matches the RV systolic pressure, which is approximately 25 mm Hg.
  • Wedge:  The catheter has a small balloon at its tip that allows it to lodge in a distal pulmonary artery (
    Right heart catheterization
    ).  The pressure at this location is known as the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP).  When wedged, the catheter tip is isolated from the proximal PA pressure (due to the balloon) and detects only pressure transmitted backward from the pulmonary veins and LA.  Therefore, PCWP is a surrogate for LA pressure (LAP) (
    figure 3
    ).  Normally, PCWP is 5-8 mm Hg.


Pressures collected during right heart catheterization are used to calculate PVR.

Calculation of PVR



From the Ohm law, the pressure drop across a circuit is equal to the flow multiplied by the resistance of the circuit (ΔP = Q × R).  In the pulmonary circulation:



  • ΔP is the difference between the main PA and LA.  Therefore, ΔP = mPAP − LAP.
    • mPAP = ⅓ × sPAP + ⅔ × dPAP = ⅓ × 25 + ⅔ × 10 = 15 mm Hg in healthy adults (because more time is spent in diastole than in systole).  As discussed previously, PAP is measured during right-sided heart catheterization of the main pulmonary artery.
    • LAP ≈ PCWP = 8 mm Hg in healthy adults.  As discussed previously, PCWP is measured during right-sided heart catheterization by occluding the distal pulmonary artery.
  • Q is the CO, or the total flow through the lungs.  CO is measured during right-sided heart catheterization using thermodilution (temperature curve after cold bolus injection into the PA) or the Fick method (difference in oxygen saturation between arterial and mixed venous blood).  Under normal conditions, CO ≈ 5 L/min.


Therefore, substituting these values into ΔP = Q × R, the equation becomes (mPAP − LAP) = CO × PVR.  Rearranging this equation yields PVR = (mPAP − LAP) / CO ≈ (15 − 8)/5 = 1.4 mm Hg / (L/min) = 1.4 Wood units (wU).  (To convert between wU and dynes·s/cm5, the units of the International System of Units, multiply by 80.)

Interpretation of PVR



Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as elevated mean PAP >20 mm Hg.  PH can occur with elevated or normal PVR:



  • PH with elevated PVR (≥3 wU):  In this scenario, PH is due to remodeling of the PAs and arterioles (the resistance vessels).  Known as precapillary PH, this encompasses PA hypertension (PAH, Group 1), PH due to chronic lung disease or hypoxemia (Group 3), and PH due to chronic pulmonary thromboembolism (Group 4).
  • PH with normal PVR (<3 wU):  In this scenario, PH is due to the transmission of venous pressure backward from the left atrium.  Known as postcapillary PH, this encompasses PH due to left-sided heart disease (eg, heart failure) or mitral valve disease (Group 2).  This is the most common cause of PH in the United States.  PCWP is expected to be elevated (eg, >15 mm Hg).

Determinants of PVR



PVR is determined by vascular tone, compression, recruitment, and remodeling.

Vascular tone



The balance between endogenous vasoconstrictors and vasodilators sets the vascular tone.



  • The major pulmonary vasodilators include nitric oxide and prostacyclin (or prostaglandin I2).
  • The major pulmonary vasoconstrictors include endothelin-1 and catecholamines (eg, epinephrine).  Pulmonary vasoconstriction is also stimulated by hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and acidosis, as well as by other vascular mediators such as angiotensin II, serotonin, and leukotrienes.

Vascular compression



Pulmonary capillaries are divided into extraalveolar (interstitial) and intraalveolar vessels.



  • At low lung volumes (near residual volume), extraalveolar vessels are compressed, but intraalveolar vessels remain open.
  • Conversely, at high lung volumes (near total lung capacity), extraalveolar vessels are open, whereas intraalveolar vessels are compressed.


Both vessel types are maximally open at intermediate lung volumes (near functional residual capacity) (

figure 4
).



Like alveolar volume, alveolar pressure has a direct effect on vascular compression.  High positive airway pressure (eg, mechanical ventilation) can compress all capillaries, raising PVR.

Vascular recruitment



At rest, only around 66% of the pulmonary vessels are open.  The remaining 33%, particularly at the lung apices, are unperfused.  During exertion, increased CO recruits these underperfused vessels while the other vessels distend to accommodate the higher blood volume.  This combination of recruitment and distension helps keep PVR stable despite increased blood flow.

Vascular remodeling



Normal PA have a relatively thin wall.  In PH, the arteries can undergo structural changes, including neointimal hyperplasia, smooth muscle thickening, and adventitial fibrosis (

figure 5
).  The vascular bed can be obliterated by emphysema or obstructed by chronic thromboemboli.



Remodeled vessels progressively lose their ability to respond to vasodilators and vasoconstrictors.  In advanced stages, they may become completely unresponsive.  These structural changes are typically irreversible and contribute to elevated PVR.

RV function

RV versus LV



The RV has several key functional differences from the LV:



  • Preload tolerance:  The RV adapts well to sudden increases in preload due to its high compliance; in contrast, the LV adapts poorly due to its low compliance (eg, volume overload can quickly lead to pulmonary congestion and edema).
  • Afterload tolerance:  The LV adapts well to sudden increases in afterload, whereas the RV adapts poorly (eg, a sudden increase in PA pressure, such as acute pulmonary embolism, can quickly lead to RV dilation and failure).
  • Contraction:  RV myocytes are arrayed linearly, so the ventricle contracts lengthwise, and RV ejection fraction is best assessed by longitudinal shortening.  In contrast, LV myocytes are arrayed helically, so the ventricle contracts torsionally, and LV ejection fraction is best assessed by circumferential contraction.
  • Ventricular interdependence:  The LV "owns" the septum, whereas the RV "borrows" the septum for contractile efficiency.  RV pressure overload (eg, severe PH) or pericardial constriction (eg, tuberculosis) leads to septal bowing into the LV, compromising its filling and subsequent output (eg, pulsus paradoxus).  Conversely, LV pressure overload does not move the septum to the right and has minimal impact on RV filling.
  • Coronary perfusion:  The LV is perfused only during diastole when intraventricular pressure drops below coronary artery pressure.  In contrast, the RV, with its lower pressure, is perfused throughout the cardiac cycle (
    figure 6
    ).  Therefore, the RV is more vulnerable to hypotension and ischemia due to its reliance on continuous perfusion.

RV-PA coupling



As discussed, the RV is much more afterload sensitive than the LV.  If too sudden, even a small increase in PAP (eg, 20 mm Hg) can cause acute RV dysfunction.  This explains why signs of RV dysfunction (eg, peripheral edema, jugular venous distension) typically appear earlier than signs of low CO (eg, hypotension, cool extremities).



Over long periods, the RV hypertrophies to adapt to high afterload.  This maintains ventriculoarterial (RV-PA) coupling despite the high PAP.  Patients with chronic PH can often have PAP approaching or even exceeding systemic pressures but appear remarkably well compensated due to RV adaptation.  However, some conditions can induce concurrent myocardial fibrosis (eg, scleroderma, sarcoidosis), impairing RV coupling and leading to earlier failure and more significant symptoms at comparatively lower PAP.  RV coupling is also impaired by factors that depress myocardial contractility (eg, cytokines, ischemia, acidosis, beta blockers).  Coupling can be conceptualized as the ratio of RV contractility to RV afterload.

Summary



The pulmonary circulation is a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-compliance system that transports blood from the right side of the heart, through the lungs, and to the left side of the heart.  Pulmonary vascular resistance is influenced by vascular tone (eg, nitric oxide, endothelin-1), physical compression (eg, high lung volume), vessel recruitment (eg, exercise), and structural remodeling (eg, medial thickening).  The right ventricle is highly sensitive to afterload and can acutely fail, with sudden increases in pulmonary artery pressure.
